My name is Sarah Henderson. I’m a third
year student. I am studying History. My degree

6.text:
programme is made up of tutorials, seminars,
lectures, and independent learning, and I’m

12.text:
going to be talking about my experiences of
independent learning.

16.text:
Independent learning is learning done in your
own time to expand your knowledge upon certain

21.text:
subjects and topics that you may have covered
in lectures, seminars, or tutorials. Typically

26.text:
if you want to independently learn you would
go to the library and get sources, or consult

32.text:
course handbooks to see what else you would
need to read. Typically I would go and do

36.text:
my independent learning either where I’m
living, in my flat, or I would go to the library

41.text:
to do extra study, or I might find somewhere
different to mix up the place and vary places

46.text:
that I would work; so coffee shops, or study
in the History department. I would typically

51.text:
spend about four to six hours a day learning
independently.

56.text:
Learning independently at the University of
Edinburgh is a very different experience from

59.text:
learning independently at high school. You
have to really think yourself about what you

64.text:
are going to study, what you are not going
to study, what books you’re going to find,

68.text:
what books you’re not going to find. You’re
not given chapters to read necessarily, you’re

71.text:
expected to be able to find these chapters
for yourself. Furthermore you’re not going

76.text:
to be forced to do the reading or given homework,
you have to take it upon yourself to do that

81.text:
reading by yourself with no extra tuition
given.

85.text:
Independent learning really benefits me personally.
It’s really taught me about myself and how

89.text:
I have to use my time efficiently. It also
means that I really feel I’ve engaged with

94.text:
the topic material as opposed to just looking
at the bare surface when you go to lectures

98.text:
or seminars. Without the independent learning
aspect I feel that I wouldn’t be able to

103.text:
discuss stuff in depth and I wouldn’t be
able to actually gain as much insight and

106.text:
knowledge into my particular topic.
Initially, it can be really daunting, however

111.text:
there is lots of support here. You can go
and talk to your tutors about the specific

116.text:
reading lists that have been given to you
in course handbooks. You can also ask your

120.text:
personal tutor if you are really struggling
with the whole concept of independent learning.

125.text:
You can also organise study groups in your
own free time that you can discuss materials

129.text:
with other people, and discuss certain problems
you’ve had.

133.text:
Without independent learning it’s very difficult
to create a good essay. You need to do independent

138.text:
learning and research so that you can find
relevant material and enough material so that

142.text:
you have a better knowledge of the subject.
And then you can create a really good argument

147.text:
and understand that argument and really think
about the ideas that you’ve been reading

151.text:
about.
I feel I really benefit from the diverse range

154.text:
of teaching methods at the University of Edinburgh.
If I just had lectures I feel that I wouldn’t

158.text:
really participate or engage in the topic
as fully. Whereas if I have lectures, seminars,

163.text:
tutorials, and independent learning, I really
feel that I really know the subject and I

168.text: can really engage in it properly and fully.
